intro: Asclepias crassinervis, commonly known as the broad-veined milkweed, is a species of flowering plant in the family Apocynaceae. It is native to the southeastern United States, where it thrives in moist, sandy soils along stream banks and wetlands. The plant produces clusters of fragrant, pinkish-white flowers that attract pollinators such as butterflies and bees. Its leaves are broad and have prominent, parallel veins, giving it its common name. Asclepias crassinervis is also an important host plant for the monarch butterfly, supporting the life cycle of this iconic species.
